The best Pastrami sandwich I ever had was at a shopping center near my house, and it was insanely simple but it won culinary awards all over the city. It had nothing but double-thick cut Rye bread, a single thin-sliced dill pickle, mustard, and a ton of thin-sliced pastrami. Cost ten bucks, and was worth every penny. This from someone that considers  Chili's 'prohibitively expensive' lol

While that's true of a hot gravy, Sam, you can easily take out a bit of liquid from the sauce early. Then place it in the freezer to cool it. You can then mix your slurry with the cooled sauce and then add it back in with the pan half off the heat to help with combining. It can make a difference too, depending on the water in your area. Just an alternative one, albeit a little more thought ahead of time one. But I love this ide and have been dying for a good pastrami sandwich. Can be so hard to find and so expensive when you do find it!

Big fan of this channel.  I just discovered it when searching how to make a patty melt.  That led me down a rabbit hole of making the burrito where he forgot to add the rice and then the next day made his baked ziti.  Then I made this chicken breast where he pounded out and cooked it on the grill. Probably the most valuable thing I picked up. You have to make it even thickness and add a pat of quality butter.  I have been cooking chicken breast wrong my whole life.  At this point I had to subscribe.  So, I live in alaska and am a frequent hunter and fisherman.  Lots of wild sockeye, bear, moose and some caribou in my box freezer.  I was curious if you would do an episode on making a recipe with wild game sometime.  Thanks for the great content sam.

Most seedless fruit is actually cloned from a parent tree/vine that out of pure chance happened to bear seedless fruit. The downside is that because all these trees/vines are cloned, your crop is super genetically homogenous which ain't so good. If a nasty blight comes, your entire crop will be ruined

Sam, I work in kitchens for a while and the first thing I was told is that when I put my knife down, the blade faces away from me, always. It really makes sense and its an important habit. Having the blade facing you can be very dangerous. You must also place the knife at the top of your work areas, not on the sides. Stay safe, you are a great cook regardless.

Hey Sam I'm from Chicago don't know if you've ever been here or not but we have a staple sandwich called the Italian beef and we usually have it dipped in the gravy/juice it would be cool if you did a take on it and use that onion soup to make the sandwich complete if you haven't tried it you should it's a life changer!

No worries about the cut. It's a badge of honor. I had a guy that was fixing a stove in our restaurant roll out from under it while I was cutting something and I took the top third of my finger off. I was about 9am. I went to the hospital, they reattached it, gave me a bunch of meds, bound it up, told me to relax for a month, and instead I went back in and finished my shift. Chefs don't experience pain, they experience learning from their mistakes or ripping the fucking heads off of people around them that make mistakes that lead them to looking at their own finger on a cutting board.

Nice Pastrami sandwich and done authentically.  There is also another version to this, a Pastrami dip on a French Roll, yummy. One half of the roll is Dipped in the aujus, finely shaved pastrami added with dill pickle slices, yellow mustard and topped with the undipped roll half. Some don't like the pickles and mustard which is easy to leave off. For those who haven't had a Pastrami meal of any kind should give these a try, they truly are satisfying !  Half of the experience is getting a good quality fresh for the day french roll.
